question:
Which is the largest sea located in the North Indian Ocean, covering an area of about 3.86 million square kilometres?

SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning)
solution:
• The Arabian Sea is the largest sea located in the northern part of the Indian Ocean.
  • It covers an area of approximately 86 million square kilometres, making it significantly larger than the other options listed.
  • It is bordered by India to the east, Pakistan and Iran to the north, and the Arabian Peninsula to the west.
  • The Indus River flows into it, and it connects to the Red Sea through the Gulf of Aden.
  • The Arabian Sea is a vital route for international maritime trade, especially between India, Africa, and Europe.

Additional Information:

  • Major ports along the Arabian Sea include Mumbai, Karachi, and Gwadar.
  • Important island groups: Lakshadweep (India), Socotra (Yemen).
  • It plays a key role in the monsoon wind system, influencing climate in South Asia.

question:
Which of the following is the largest crustal plate on Earth with an area of over 103,000,000 km2?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Pacific Plate is the largest crustal plate on Earth.
  • It spans an area of over 103 million square kilometres, making it significantly larger than any other tectonic plate.
  • This plate covers most of the Pacific Ocean floor and extends to the coasts of North America, Asia, and Oceania.
  • It is an oceanic plate, composed mainly of dense basaltic crust.
  • The Pacific Plate is involved in several subduction zones, leading to high tectonic activity including earthquakes and volcanic eruptions (e.g., Ring of Fire).

Additional Information:

  • Other large plates: Eurasian Plate (~67 million km²), African Plate (~61 million km²).
  • The Ring of Fire, one of the most seismically active regions in the world, is due to the movement of the Pacific Plate.
  • It moves northwest at about 7–11 cm per year.

question:
In the context of water bodies, Neap Tides occur :

SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_1: when the earth, moon and sun line up in a straight line
option_2: when the sun and moon are on the opposite sides
option_3: when there is so much interference by continents
option_4: when the sun and moon are at right angles to each other
solution:
• Neap tides occur when the Sun and Moon are at right angles (90°) to each other, relative to the Earth.
  • This typically happens during the first and third quarters of the Moon.
  • In this alignment, the gravitational forces of the Moon and the Sun partially cancel each other out, leading to lower high tides and higher low tides.
  • As a result, the tidal range (difference between high and low tide) is minimum during neap tides.
  • Neap tides are the opposite of spring tides, which have the maximum tidal range.

Additional Information:

  • Spring tides occur when the Sun, Moon, and Earth are in a straight line (new moon and full moon).
  • Tides are influenced by gravitational pull and centrifugal force between Earth, Moon, and Sun.
  • Neap tides occur twice a month.

question:
Which of the following is a landlocked Salt Lake in South-West Asia between Israel and Jordan?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Dead Sea is a landlocked salt lake located in South-West Asia, between Israel and Jordan.
  • It is one of the saltiest water bodies on Earth, with salinity levels over 30%, making it nearly 10 times saltier than ocean water.
  • Due to its high salinity, no aquatic life such as fish can survive in it — hence the name "Dead Sea."
  • It lies at the lowest elevation on Earth’s surface, around 430 meters below sea level.
  • The Jordan River is its main inflow source.

Additional Information:

  • The Dead Sea is a major site for tourism and mineral extraction.
  • Its high salt content allows people to float easily on its surface.
  • The water level is rapidly decreasing due to diversion of the Jordan River and mineral extraction activities.

question:
Which ocean is encircling the continent of Antarctica and extends northward to 60 degrees south latitude?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Southern Ocean is the ocean that encircles the continent of Antarctica.
  • It extends northward up to 60° south latitude, where it meets the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans.
  • Officially recognized as the fifth ocean by the International Hydrographic Organization (IHO), the Southern Ocean plays a major role in global ocean circulation.
  • It is characterized by the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC), which flows from west to east around Antarctica.
  • The Southern Ocean is crucial for regulating Earth's climate by absorbing heat and carbon dioxide.

Additional Information:

  • The Southern Ocean is the youngest named ocean, recognized officially in 2000.
  • It includes parts of the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans south of 60°S.
  • It is home to unique marine species adapted to extreme cold.

question:
The name of the strait between the Pacific and Arctic oceans, separating the Chukchi Peninsula of the Russian Far East from the Seward Peninsula of Alaska, is the :

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Bering Strait is the strait that separates the Chukchi Peninsula of Russia (in the Russian Far East) from the Seward Peninsula of Alaska, USA.
  • It connects the Pacific Ocean (via the Bering Sea) with the Arctic Ocean (via the Chukchi Sea).
  • The strait is approximately 82 km (51 miles) wide at its narrowest point.
  • It lies just south of the Arctic Circle and serves as a boundary between Asia and North America.
  • During the Ice Age, a land bridge called Beringia existed here, believed to have allowed early human migration from Asia to the Americas.

Additional Information:

  • Davis Strait lies between Greenland and Canada.
  • Florida Strait separates Florida (USA) and Cuba.
  • Messina Strait separates Sicily from mainland Italy.

question:
The peninsular plateau of India was apart of which continent earlier?

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Peninsular Plateau of India is geologically one of the oldest landmasses on Earth.
  • It was once a part of the ancient supercontinent Gondwana, which existed around 200 million years ago.
  • Gondwana included present-day Africa, South America, Antarctica, Australia, and the Indian subcontinent.
  • During the continental drift, the Indian plate broke away and moved northwards, eventually colliding with the Eurasian plate and forming the Himalayas.
  • Hence, the Indian Peninsular Plateau was earlier part of the African landmass under Gondwana.

Additional Information:

  • The Peninsular Plateau is composed mainly of igneous and metamorphic rocks.
  • It is rich in mineral resources, especially in the Chota Nagpur Plateau region.
  • Major rivers like Godavari, Krishna, and Mahanadi originate from this plateau.

question:
In 1596, who suggested in his work 'Thesaurus Geographicus' that the continents of the earth were not always located in their present positions ?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• In 1596, Abraham Ortelius, a Flemish cartographer and geographer, proposed an early idea of continental drift.
  • In his work titled "Thesaurus Geographicus", Ortelius suggested that the continents were once joined together and had drifted apart over time.
  • He noticed the matching coastlines of continents like South America and Africa, and hypothesized that they were once connected.
  • Though his ideas were not widely accepted at the time, they are considered a precursor to modern plate tectonics theory.

Additional Information:

  • Alfred Wegener later formalized the continental drift theory in 1912.
  • Dan McKenzie contributed significantly to plate tectonic theory in the 1960s.
  • Louis Agassiz was known for the Ice Age theory.
  • Georges Cuvier is associated with catastrophism and paleontology.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a part of the ocean floor?

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
option_3: The deep sea shelf
option_4: The deep sea plain
solution:
• The ocean floor consists of various distinct features formed due to tectonic and sedimentary processes.
  • The main parts of the ocean floor include:
    1. Continental Shelf – a shallow, submerged edge of the continent.
    2. Continental Slope – the steep slope connecting the shelf to the deep ocean.
    3. Deep Sea Plain (or Abyssal Plain) – flat, deep regions of the ocean floor.
    4. Oceanic Trenches, Mid-ocean Ridges, and Seamounts are also part of the ocean floor.
  • However, "Deep Sea Shelf" is not a recognized or scientifically classified part of the ocean floor. It appears to be a misleading or incorrect term.

Additional Information:

  • The continental shelf is important for marine life and resource exploration.
  • Abyssal plains are among the flattest, smoothest regions on Earth.
  • Continental margins include both the shelf and slope.

question:
The thermocline layer is the ______ layer of the ocean.

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The thermocline layer is the second layer of the ocean, located below the surface (mixed) layer and above the deep ocean layer.
  • It is characterized by a rapid decrease in temperature with increasing depth.
  • This layer acts as a barrier to vertical mixing of water, separating warmer surface water from the colder deep water.
  • The depth and thickness of the thermocline vary with latitude and seasons, being more prominent in tropical regions.

Additional Information:

  • Ocean layers (from top to bottom):
    1. Surface/Mixed Layer – warm, well-mixed due to winds.
    2. Thermocline Layer – steep temperature gradient.
    3. Deep Ocean Layer – cold, stable temperature.
  • The thermocline plays a key role in heat distribution and marine life distribution.

question:
In 1962, who published 'The History of Ocean Basins', which outlined the theory of how tectonic plates couldmove, later called 'sea floor spreading' ?

Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• In 1962, Harry Hammond Hess, an American geologist and naval officer, published a groundbreaking paper titled “The History of Ocean Basins.”
  • In this work, he proposed the theory later known as "Sea Floor Spreading".
  • According to this theory, new oceanic crust is formed at mid-ocean ridges and moves outward, pushing older crust away.
  • This concept provided a mechanism for Alfred Wegener’s Continental Drift theory, laying the foundation for modern Plate Tectonics.

Additional Information:

  • Alfred Wegener proposed the Continental Drift theory in 1912 but lacked a mechanism.
  • Sea floor spreading explained the formation of ocean basins and the movement of continents.
  • Mid-ocean ridges, like the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, are key features supporting this theory.

question:
Which is the deepest point of Earth's oceans with a depth of 11,022 metres?

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
option_1: Pacific Ocean's Mariana Trench
option_2: Indian Ocean's Java Trench
option_3: Atlantic Ocean's Puerto Rico Trench
option_4: Arctic Ocean's Eurasian Basin
solution:
• The deepest point in Earth’s oceans is found in the Mariana Trench, located in the western Pacific Ocean.
  • The Challenger Deep, the lowest known point in the trench, has a depth of approximately 11,022 metres (about 36,161 feet).
  • It lies to the east of the Mariana Islands, near Guam.
  • The trench was first sounded by HMS Challenger in 1875, and later explored in more detail using deep-sea submersibles.

Additional Information:

  • Java Trench (Indian Ocean) – depth ~7,258 metres.
  • Puerto Rico Trench (Atlantic Ocean) – depth ~8,376 metres.
  • Eurasian Basin (Arctic Ocean) – depth ~5,449 metres.
  • The Mariana Trench is part of a subduction zone, where the Pacific Plate is being pushed beneath the smaller Mariana Plate.

question:
Which of the following is the correct match between column-A and column-B?

Column- AColumn- B

(Elements in earth crust)(Total % in earth crust)

i. Oxygena. 8%

ii. Siliconb. 28%

iii. Aluminium c. 47%

iv. Iron d. 5%

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
We are matching elements in Earth's crust (Column A) with their approximate percentage composition (Column B):

  • i. Oxygen – c. 47%

    ➤ Oxygen is the most abundant element in Earth's crust, making up about 46–47% by weight.

  • ii. Silicon – b. 28%

    ➤ Silicon is the second most abundant, contributing about 27–28%.

  • iii. Aluminium – a. 8%

    ➤ Aluminium ranks third, with approximately 8% presence.

  • iv. Iron – d. 5%

    ➤ Iron makes up about 5% of the Earth's crust.

So the correct match is:

(i - c), (ii - b), (iii - a), (iv - d)

Answer: (c)

question:
Continental Shelf which is the shallowest part of the ocean has an average gradient of:

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The Continental Shelf is the shallowest and gently sloping part of the ocean floor, located at the edge of a continent.
  • It extends from the shoreline to the continental slope, with an average depth of up to 200 meters.
  • The average gradient (slope) of the continental shelf is typically 1° or even less, making it a very gradual incline.
  • Despite its shallow nature, it holds rich marine biodiversity and mineral resources, and is crucial for fishing and offshore drilling.

Additional Information:

  • The shelf can be wide (over 1000 km) or narrow, depending on the coastal region.
  • Beyond the shelf lies the continental slope, which has a steeper gradient.
  • Continental shelves are often considered submerged extensions of the continents.

question:
Living organisms have been on Earth for how much percent of Earth's history?

SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Earth is estimated to be about 54 billion years old.
  • The earliest evidence of life dates back to around 3.5 to 3.8 billion years ago, with microbial life like cyanobacteria.
  • This means life has existed for approximately 80% of Earth's history.
  • The timeline includes simple unicellular organisms in early stages, and complex multicellular life evolving much later (around 600 million years ago).

Additional Information:

  • First multicellular organisms appeared around 600 million years ago.
  • Human beings have existed for only about 0.004% of Earth’s history.
  • Life has survived through five major mass extinction events.

question:
Choose the correct statement(s) related to ‘continentality’.

a. The sea exerts a moderating influence on climate.

b. As the distance from the sea increases, the people experience extreme weather conditions.

c. As one goes from the surface of the earth to higher altitudes, the atmosphere becomes less dense and temperature decreases.

SSC CPO05/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The term continentality refers to the climatic condition of a region based on its distance from the sea.
  • The sea has a moderating effect on climate: it reduces temperature extremes, keeping summers cooler and winters milder — this is statement (a) and it is correct.
  • As distance from the sea increases, the moderating effect decreases, and areas experience extreme temperature variations — hotter summers and colder winters. So, statement (b) is also correct.
  • However, statement (c) is about altitude, not continentality. Though it's factually correct (temperature decreases with altitude), it is not directly related to the concept of continentality.

So, the correct statements related to continentality are:- a and b

question:
What does El Niño refer to ?

SSC MTS 06/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• El Niño refers to a warm ocean current that develops along the coast of Peru and Ecuador in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
  • It is part of a larger climate pattern called El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO).
  • During El Niño years, sea surface temperatures rise significantly in the central and eastern Pacific.
  • This disrupts normal wind patterns and affects global weather, often causing droughts, floods, and warmer winters in various parts of the world.

Additional Information:

  • El Niño occurs irregularly every 2–7 years.
  • It is often followed or preceded by La Niña, which brings cooler than normal ocean temperatures.
  • The term “El Niño” means “The Little Boy” in Spanish, referring to the Christ child, as it often appears around Christmas.

question:
Which of the following oceans is surrounded by the continent of North America and South America to the east?

SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.
  • It is bounded on the east by North and South America, and on the west by Asia and Australia.
  • The given question asks for an ocean that has North and South America to its east, which clearly matches the Pacific Ocean.

Additional Information:

  • The Pacific Ocean covers an area of about 168 million square kilometers.
  • It contains the Mariana Trench, the deepest point in the world’s oceans.
  • Important water bodies connected to it include the Bering Sea, Coral Sea, and South China Sea.
  • Major current: North and South Equatorial Currents, and the Kuroshio Current.
  • It plays a vital role in global climate patterns like El Niño and La Niña.

question:
Which of the following oceans extends into the Mediterranean Sea ?

SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Mediterranean Sea is a large, enclosed sea connected to the Atlantic Ocean.
  • It is linked to the Atlantic by the Strait of Gibraltar, a narrow passage between southern Spain and northern Morocco.
  • Therefore, the ocean that extends into the Mediterranean Sea is the Atlantic Ocean.

Additional Information:

  • The Mediterranean Sea borders Europe, Asia, and Africa.
  • It is one of the world’s busiest waterways in terms of maritime trade.
  • The name "Mediterranean" means "in the middle of the land" (from Latin).
  • Important ports include Barcelona, Marseille, Alexandria, and Istanbul.
  • The Strait of Gibraltar is only about 13 km wide, making it a strategic and geopolitical chokepoint.

question:
The mohororvicic (Moho) discontinuity separates ?

SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Earth's lithosphere and asthenosphere
option_2: Earth's atmosphere and hydrosphere
option_3: Earth's crust and the inner core
option_4: Earth's crust and the mantle
solution:
• The Mohorovičić Discontinuity, commonly called the Moho, is the boundary between the Earth's crust and the mantle.
  • It was discovered in 1909 by Croatian seismologist Andrija Mohorovičić, who noticed a sudden change in the velocity of seismic waves at this depth.
  • This discontinuity lies at an average depth of about:
    • 5–10 km beneath the oceanic crust
    • 30–50 km beneath the continental crust
  • The change in seismic wave speed is due to a transition from less dense crustal rocks to denser mantle rocks.

Additional Information:

  • The Moho is not the same as the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary, which lies deeper.
  • It helps scientists study plate tectonics, earthquake propagation, and Earth’s interior structure.
  • The mantle below the Moho is primarily composed of peridotite, a dense, magnesium-rich rock.

question:
Due to the attraction of the sun and the moon, what is the frequency of up and falls of ocean water in a day ?

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The rise and fall of ocean water due to the gravitational attraction of the Sun and the Moon is known as tides.
  • In most coastal areas, there are two high tides and two low tides approximately every 24 hours.
  • This is due to the Moon’s gravitational pull, which creates a bulge of water on the side of Earth facing the Moon and another on the opposite side.
  • The result is a semi-diurnal tidal cycle, meaning two tidal cycles per day.

Additional Information:

  • The time between two high tides (or two low tides) is approximately 12 hours and 25 minutes.
  • The Moon has a stronger influence on tides than the Sun because it is closer to Earth.
  • During new moon and full moon, tides are higher (spring tides); during quarter phases, tides are lower (neap tides).

question:
Which is the correct sequence of oceans according to size (from largest to smallest) ?

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (2nd shift)
option_1: Pacific Ocean > Antarctic Ocean > Indian Ocean > Atlantic Ocean
option_2: Pacific Ocean > Indian Ocean > Antarctic Ocean > Atlantic Ocean
option_3: Pacific Ocean > Atlantic Ocean > Indian Ocean > Antarctic Ocean
option_4: Pacific Ocean > Indian Ocean > Atlantic Ocean > Antarctic Ocean
solution:
To arrange the oceans by size from largest to smallest, we look at their total surface areas:

  1. Pacific Ocean – ~168 million sq. km
  2. Atlantic Ocean – ~85 million sq. km
  3. Indian Ocean – ~70 million sq. km
  4. Southern (Antarctic) Ocean – ~21 million sq. km
  5. Arctic Ocean – ~15 million sq. km (not listed in the options)

So, the correct sequence is:

Pacific Ocean > Atlantic Ocean > Indian Ocean > Antarctic Ocean

Answer: (c)

question:
The percentage of earth's water found in the oceans is _________.

SSC CGL 01/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Earth’s total water is distributed among oceans, glaciers, groundwater, rivers, lakes, and the atmosphere.
  • The majority of Earth’s water (about 97.2%) is found in the oceans, making them the largest reservoir of water on the planet.
  • The remaining 8% is freshwater, most of which is locked in ice caps and glaciers, with only a tiny fraction available in rivers, lakes, and groundwater.

Additional Information:

  • About 2.15% of Earth's water is in glaciers and ice caps.
  • Only around 0.65% is freshwater available as groundwater, lakes, and rivers.
  • Despite covering ~71% of Earth’s surface, ocean water is saline and not directly usable for drinking without desalination.

question:
How thick is the lithosphere?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The lithosphere is the outermost rigid layer of the Earth, comprising the crust and the uppermost part of the mantle.
  • Its thickness varies depending on the region:
    • Under oceanic crust, it is thinner (around 10–100 km).
    • Under continental crust, it can be much thicker (up to 200 km).
  • Hence, the lithosphere generally ranges from 10 to 200 km in thickness.

Additional Information:

  • The lithosphere is broken into tectonic plates that float over the asthenosphere, which is semi-fluid.
  • It plays a critical role in plate tectonics, earthquakes, and volcanic activity.
  • Beneath the lithosphere lies the asthenosphere, a partially molten zone that allows plate movement.

question:
The crust is the Earth's outermost layer that is less than ______ percent of Earth by mass, with oceanic crust and continental crust often consisting of more felsic rocks.

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Earth's crust is the outermost solid layer of our planet.
  • Despite being the surface layer, it makes up less than 1% of Earth's total mass.
  • The crust is of two types:
    • Oceanic crust – thinner and composed mostly of mafic rocks like basalt.
    • Continental crust – thicker and composed mainly of felsic rocks like granite.
  • These felsic rocks are rich in silicon and aluminum, which makes the continental crust lighter but thicker.

Additional Information:

  • Beneath the crust lies the mantle, which constitutes about 84% of Earth's volume.
  • The core (inner + outer) makes up the remaining ~15% of Earth's mass.
  • The crust's average thickness is:
    • 5–10 km under oceans
    • 30–50 km under continents

question:
Movement of fault lines can cause:

SSC CPO 09/11/2022(Evening)
solution:
• Fault lines are fractures or zones of weakness in the Earth’s crust where two blocks of land have moved relative to each other.
  • When stress builds up along a fault line and is suddenly released, it causes the ground to shake violently — this is known as an earthquake.
  • The movement of tectonic plates along these fault lines is the primary cause of earthquakes.

Additional Information:

  • Major fault lines include the San Andreas Fault (USA) and Himalayan Frontal Thrust (India).
  • Earthquakes are measured using the Richter scale or Moment Magnitude Scale (Mw).
  • Fault movement can be of different types: normal fault, reverse fault, and strike-slip fault.

question:
What is the average salinity of the Indian ocean?

Graduate Level 03/08/2022 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• Salinity refers to the amount of dissolved salts (mainly sodium chloride) in ocean water and is commonly measured in parts per thousand (o/oo).
  • The average salinity of the Indian Ocean is approximately 35 o/oo (or 35‰), which means 35 grams of salt per 1,000 grams of seawater.
  • This value is similar to the global ocean average and varies slightly depending on evaporation, precipitation, river inflow, and ocean currents.

Additional Information:

  • The Arabian Sea tends to have higher salinity due to high evaporation and low rainfall.
  • The Bay of Bengal has lower salinity because of heavy river inflow and more precipitation.
  • Ocean salinity affects density, circulation, and marine ecosystems.

question:
Tsunami is NOT caused by:

Higher Secondary 03/08/2022 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• A tsunami is a series of large ocean waves typically caused by sudden disturbances on or under the ocean floor.
  • Common causes of tsunamis include:
    • Undersea earthquakes (most common)
    • Volcanic eruptions
    • Undersea landslides
    • Occasionally, meteorite impacts
  • However, hurricanes (also called cyclones or typhoons), although they can cause storm surges and coastal flooding, do not cause tsunamis.
  • Storm surges are different phenomena caused by atmospheric pressure and wind, not tectonic activity.

Additional Information:

  • The word “Tsunami” comes from Japanese: "tsu" = harbor and "nami" = wave.
  • Tsunamis can travel at speeds over 800 km/h in deep ocean water.
  • Warning systems like the Indian Tsunami Early Warning Centre (ITEWC) monitor seismic activity to alert coastal areas.

question:
Which of the following is a warm current?

SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Ocean currents are large-scale flows of ocean water, classified as warm or cold depending on their temperature relative to surrounding waters.
  • The Gulf Stream is a warm ocean current that originates in the Gulf of Mexico and flows across the Atlantic Ocean towards the western coast of Europe.
  • It plays a major role in warming the climate of Western Europe.

Let’s review the options:

  • (a) Labrador Current – Cold current (flows southward from the Arctic Ocean along the coast of Canada)
  • (b) Falkland Current – Cold current (flows northward along the southeastern coast of South America)
  • (c) Canary Current – Cold current (flows southward along the northwestern coast of Africa)
  • (d) Gulf Stream – Warm current (flows from the Gulf of Mexico toward the North Atlantic)

Additional Information:

  • Warm currents generally originate near the equator and flow toward the poles.
  • Cold currents usually begin in polar regions and flow toward the equator.
  • Currents influence climate, marine biodiversity, and navigation routes.

question:
The plate movements on earth are classified into ______ types.

SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The movement of tectonic plates on Earth's surface is classified into three main types, based on the direction of their interaction at plate boundaries.

The three types of plate movements are:

  1. Divergent Boundaries
    • Plates move away from each other.
    • Example: Mid-Atlantic Ridge
  2. Convergent Boundaries
    • Plates move towards each other, leading to collision or subduction.
    • Example: Himalayan mountain formation (Indian plate colliding with Eurasian plate)
  3. Transform Boundaries
    • Plates slide past each other horizontally.
    • Example: San Andreas Fault in California

These movements are responsible for earthquakes, volcanic activity, mountain building, and formation of oceanic trenches.

Additional Information:

  • The theory of plate tectonics explains the structure and motion of Earth's lithosphere.
  • Earth's lithosphere is broken into large tectonic plates that float on the semi-fluid asthenosphere.

question:
Ocean acidification is the ongoing decrease in the pH of the Earth’s oceans, caused by the uptake of ______ from the atmosphere.

SSC MTS 15/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Ocean acidification refers to the gradual decrease in the pH of ocean water, making it more acidic.
  • This process is primarily caused by the uptake of carbon dioxide (CO₂) from the atmosphere.
  • When CO₂ dissolves in seawater, it forms carbonic acid (H₂CO₃), which releases hydrogen ions, lowering the pH.

Chemical Reaction:

  • This increase in H⁺ ions reduces carbonate availability, affecting marine organisms like corals, mollusks, and plankton, which need carbonate ions to build their shells and skeletons.

Additional Information:

  • Ocean acidification threatens marine biodiversity and food chains.
  • Over 30% of human-generated CO₂ has been absorbed by oceans since the industrial revolution.
  • Methane, nitrogen, and argon are not directly responsible for ocean acidification.

https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749033685759_image001.png

question:
The lowest known point on earth is called ________, which is present in the Pacific Ocean.

SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The lowest known point on Earth is the Challenger Deep, located in the Mariana Trench in the western Pacific Ocean.
  • It reaches a depth of approximately 10,929 to 11,022 metres (around 36,000 feet) below sea level.
  • It was named after the British survey ship HMS Challenger, which first measured its depth in 1875.

Incorrect Options:

  • (a) Factorial Deep – Not a real geological feature.
  • (c) Great Blue Hole – A large marine sinkhole off the coast of Belize, but not the deepest point on Earth.
  • (d) Great Barrier Reef – The world’s largest coral reef system, located off the coast of Australia, not a deep ocean point.

Additional Information:

  • The Challenger Deep has been explored by unmanned submersibles and a few manned missions, including James Cameron's solo dive in 2012.
  • It is part of a subduction zone, where the Pacific Plate is being forced under the Mariana Plate.

question:
In coastal areas, during the night, wind blows from land to sea because:

SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Morning)
option_1: low pressure is created on land
option_2: land cools slower than water
option_3: water cools slower than land
option_4: high pressure is created at sea
solution:
• In coastal areas, wind direction changes between day and night due to differential heating of land and water.

During the night:

  • Land cools down faster than water because it loses heat more quickly.
  • Water retains heat longer, so it remains warmer than the land.
  • As a result, air over the land becomes cooler and denser, creating a high-pressure area.
  • The warmer air over the sea rises due to lower density, creating a low-pressure area.
  • Air moves from the high pressure (land) to the low pressure (sea) — this is called a land breeze.

Hence, wind blows from land to sea at night because water cools slower than land.

question:
The process of seepage of water into the ground is called _________.

SSC MTS 25/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The process by which water seeps or sinks into the ground through soil and porous rocks is known as infiltration.
  • This typically occurs when rainwater or surface water enters the soil and percolates down to recharge groundwater aquifers.
  • Infiltration is an important part of the water cycle and helps maintain groundwater levels.

Other options:

  • (b) Depletion – Refers to the reduction or exhaustion of resources like groundwater.
  • (c) Storage – Involves holding or collecting water, e.g., in tanks or reservoirs.
  • (d) Replenishment – Refers to restoring or refilling something (like groundwater), but it is the result, not the process.

Additional Information:

  • Factors affecting infiltration include soil type, vegetation cover, rainfall intensity, and land use.
  • Infiltration helps prevent surface runoff and soil erosion.

question:
Which water body covers an area of 1,55,58,000 𝑘𝑚2 and makes up only 4.3% of the global ocean?

SSC CHSL 24/05/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The Arctic Ocean is the smallest and shallowest of all five major oceans.
  • It covers an area of approximately 15,558,000 km², which is about 3% of the total global ocean area.
  • It is located around the North Pole, surrounded by landmasses of North America, Europe, and Asia.
  • Much of the Arctic Ocean is permanently or seasonally covered with sea ice.

Let's compare the ocean areas:

Ocean

Approximate Area (km²)

% of Global Ocean

Pacific Ocean

~168 million

~46%

Atlantic Ocean

~85 million

~23%

Indian Ocean

~70 million

~20%

Southern Ocean

~21 million

~6%

Arctic Ocean

~15.56 million

~4.3%

Additional Information:

  • The Arctic Ocean plays a key role in regulating global climate.
  • Due to climate change, Arctic ice is melting faster, impacting sea levels and ecosystems.
  • It is also a region of increasing geopolitical and commercial interest (e.g., Arctic shipping routes, oil and gas exploration).

question:
Which is the largest continental shelf in the world?

SSC CHSL 24/05/2022 (Evening)
option_1: The shelf of India
option_2: The Indian Ocean shelf
option_3: The shelf in the Pacific Ocean
option_4: The Siberian shelf in the Arctic Ocean
solution:
• The Siberian Shelf, located in the Arctic Ocean, is the largest continental shelf in the world.
  • It stretches along the northern coast of Russia and spans an area of approximately 3 million square kilometers.
  • This shelf extends up to 1,500 km from the shoreline into the Arctic Ocean.
  • It is shallow, mostly less than 50 meters deep, and remains ice-covered for much of the year.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • (a) The shelf of India – Relatively narrow and not globally significant in size.
  • (b) The Indian Ocean shelf – No single large continental shelf dominates this ocean.
  • (c) The shelf in the Pacific Ocean – Contains many small shelves but none as large as the Siberian Shelf.

Additional Information:

  • The Siberian Shelf is part of the larger Arctic continental shelf, which is of interest for oil and gas exploration.
  • It plays an important role in polar climate regulation and oceanic carbon cycles.

question:
Which of the following is a group of islands found in the tropical oceans consisting of coral reefs and a central depression?

SSC CGL 19/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• An Atoll is a ring-shaped coral reef or a series of islets that surround a central lagoon.
  • It is usually found in tropical ocean waters, particularly in the Pacific and Indian Oceans.
  • Atolls are formed from the growth of coral reefs around the rim of a sinking volcanic island. Over time, the island submerges, leaving behind a ring of coral and a central depression filled with water (the lagoon).

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Guyots – Flat-topped submerged volcanic mountains that do not form islands.
  • (c) Seamount – An underwater volcanic mountain that does not reach the ocean surface.
  • (d) Lagoon – A shallow body of water separated from a larger body by reefs or barrier islands; it is a part of an atoll, not the structure itself.

Additional Information:

  • Famous atolls: Maldives, Bikini Atoll, Funafuti (Tuvalu)
  • Atolls are rich in biodiversity and often used for fishing and tourism.

question:
Name the only sea in the world that does NOT have a land boundary.

SSC MTS 13/10/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• The Sargasso Sea is the only sea in the world that has no land boundary.
  • It is located in the North Atlantic Ocean, entirely surrounded by ocean currents rather than land.
  • The sea is bounded by the North Atlantic Subtropical Gyre, formed by:
    • Gulf Stream (west)
    • North Atlantic Current (north)
    • Canary Current (east)
    • North Atlantic Equatorial Current (south)
  • The Sargasso Sea is named after the Sargassum seaweed that floats abundantly on its surface.
  • Unlike other seas, which are partly enclosed by land, the Sargasso Sea is defined solely by oceanographic features.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Pechora Sea – Located in the Arctic Ocean, bounded by Russia.
  • (c) Amundsen Sea – Lies off the coast of West Antarctica.
  • (d) Iroise Sea – Found along the northwestern coast of France.

question:
Which of the following was NOT a part of Gondwanaland?

SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• Gondwanaland (or Gondwana) was a supercontinent that existed during the Late Paleozoic and Mesozoic eras, about 500 to 180 million years ago.
  • It included landmasses that are now present in the Southern Hemisphere.

The major present-day continents that were part of Gondwanaland:

  • India
  • Australia
  • South America
  • Africa
  • Antarctica
  • Madagascar

Not part of Gondwanaland:

  • North America was part of a different ancient supercontinent called Laurasia, not Gondwanaland.

Additional Information:

  • Gondwanaland eventually broke apart due to plate tectonic movement, leading to the formation of the continents as we know them today.
  • The concept of Gondwanaland supports the theory of continental drift, proposed by Alfred Wegener in 1912.

question:
What is the normal air pressure at sea level?

SSC CHSL 19/03/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• The normal (standard) air pressure at sea level is defined as 25 millibars (mb) or 1013.25 hPa (hectopascals).
  • This is equivalent to 1 atmosphere (atm) or 760 mm of mercury (Hg).
  • It represents the average pressure exerted by the atmosphere at sea level under standard conditions (15°C temperature).

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) 886.13 mb – Too low; typical of high-altitude or storm areas.
  • (c) 985.14 mb – Possible in low-pressure weather systems, but not standard.
  • (d) 1100.12 mb – Unusually high; higher than average even for high-pressure zones.

Additional Information:

  • Atmospheric pressure decreases with altitude.
  • Barometers are used to measure air pressure, and it is a key factor in weather forecasting.
  • Low pressure usually indicates stormy weather, while high pressure brings clear skies.

question:
India is divided into how many earthquake zones (seismic zones)?

SSC CHSL 19/03/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• India is divided into 4 seismic zones, based on the level of earthquake risk or seismic activity.
  • These zones are classified by the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) in the IS 1893:2002 code.
  • The zones are:
    1. Zone II – Low risk
    2. Zone III – Moderate risk
    3. Zone IV – High risk
    4. Zone V – Very high risk (Most seismically active)
  • Earlier, India was divided into 5 seismic zones, but Zone I (very low risk) was removed and merged into Zone II.

Important Points:

  • Zone V includes parts of Jammu & Kashmir, Northeast India, and the Andaman & Nicobar Islands.
  • Zone IV includes Delhi, northern Bihar, parts of Himachal Pradesh, etc.
  • Zone III covers Kerala, Goa, West Bengal, etc.
  • Zone II covers South India and central parts, considered least active.

Additional Information:

  • Seismic zones help in designing earthquake-resistant structures.
  • India lies at the boundary of the Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates, making the Himalayan region highly earthquake-prone.

question:
The _____ is responsible for Earth's magnetic field.

SSC CHSL 16/10/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• The Earth's magnetic field is primarily generated by the outer core, which is made up of molten iron and nickel.
  • This layer is in a liquid state, and the convection currents caused by the movement of molten metals create electric currents.
  • These electric currents, along with the Earth's rotation, generate a geodynamo effect, which is responsible for producing the magnetic field.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Inner core – Solid and very hot, but does not contribute significantly to magnetic field generation.
  • (b) Mantle – Made of silicate rocks; not involved in generating the magnetic field.
  • (d) Crust – Outermost solid layer; not involved in the magnetic field’s origin.

Additional Information:

  • The magnetic field protects Earth from harmful solar winds and cosmic radiation.
  • The field is strongest near the magnetic poles and is constantly changing due to core dynamics.
  • Evidence of magnetic field reversals (magnetic north becoming south) is preserved in igneous rocks.
